h1. XMS | Support Direct Methods

Please initiate the refinement process for integrating and providing support for the following direct methods:

* *Reboot*
* *Get Logs*
* *Reset to Default*
* *Clear Logs*

Let me know if you need any further details or assistance!
[~accountid:640f05cdb05b4e3e7da841fa] Please find the Epic and do needful as discussed

fields.description:
Add the supported methods:

[https://github.com/barcoemu/SWIT-IOT-specs/pull/23/files#diff-d98ab100ae538fb866e104c53c4f307c090f0d365f8ba70426cae93457a92839R161-R169|https://github.com/barcoemu/SWIT-IOT-specs/pull/23/files#diff-d98ab100ae538fb866e104c53c4f307c090f0d365f8ba70426cae93457a92839R161-R169] 

{noformat} "SupportedMethods": {
      "GetLogs": "Get Logs",
      "Reboot": "Reboot Device",
      "ResetToDefault": "Reset to Default",
      "ClearLogs": "Clear Logs",
      "UserDataReset": "Resets the user settings related data",
      "MSTeamsLogout": "Logs out MS Teams account from the baseunit"
}{noformat}

Note that the following methods are out of scope:

{noformat}      "TestConnection": "Checks network connectivity of device for a given interface or proxy",
      "GetInternetConnectivityStatus": "Get Internet Connectivity Status",{noformat}



*Bazaar Demo: Device methods(*Get Logs, Reboot*) Demo E-2-E*

*Environment: (Master Build BU, ciddev-XMS)*

fields.description:
This epic aims to upgrade Qt to version 6.10.1 across all supported platforms. The migration will ensure long‑term maintainability, improve performance, and align the system with the latest Qt framework. 

Planned procedure: 

# Disable hardware acceleration and perform basic functional verification on Duff, Kirin, Phoenix, and Delirium, with a focus on validating digital signage and other critical features.
# Provide a test build to the Product Owner for comparing performance against the previous Qt version.
# Complete the Qt version bump and integration into the pipeline before the end of February.

comments.body:
LATER EDIT: Resolved offline.
[~accountid:557058:87e6cd43-eeb5-478c-94f3-7a0c9f0c3e77]  Thank you, some mentions:
- We will start with local feature flags (not connected to any remote provider)
- Feature flags values depends on the environment ({{DEBUG}}/{{PRODUCTION}}) they are running. When a new feature is added, the general approach would be to have a FF attached to it with the value set to {{true}} in {{DEBUG}}, and {{false}} in {{PRODUCTION}}.
- Regarding TenTo tests: they can override the value of FeatureFlags and the environment they should run in (Debug, Prod) using ADB. It’s also the responsibility of TenTo to make absolutelly sure these overrides are cleared after tests finish. Overrides survive boot, so it’s crucial to clear them when finishing.

{quote}list of feature flags set should be visible in the logs{quote}

I’d appreciate more details. Should we do this only on boot? Or should we do it on each Feature Flag query? If we do it on boot, it will be misleading in TenTo tests as they can be overriden. But for release it will suffice, as they cannot change at runtime in release. So I would propose to have a info-level log with all FF flags at boot, and a debug-level log on each FF query/override.


{quote}feature flags can be set independently on different platforms (ex true for Duvel, false for GOD){quote}

Great point, I didn’t consider it during the development of the PoC. It’s great to know of these requirements early on, so are there any other platform that need to be considered other than Duvel and GOD? Is there any other environment consideration that would make us have different FF values? Currently we consider: Debug vs Production, Duvel vs GOD. 



{quote}preferable we can have a very small demo feature behind a feature and a knowledge sharing is given to the other feature teams{quote}

Completely agree! I will do a demo as soon as we have production-ready, dedicated repository with all the minimum requirements.

Test strategy to be discussed (may impact test setup capacity if multiple combinations are required). But this will depend on release strategy. e.g. How long will we know upfront what features will be enabled for a release. Do we always test with all features enabled on master and on release branch with only the enabled features?

fields.description:
We will have multiple teams work simulations on different features, so avoid having long living feature branches we should have feature flags.

When a new feature is created it should have a flag which is false by default.
When a feature is ready the default value can be adapted to true
at code freeze for a release the feature flag list is easy reviewable and 'locked'


Tento or a developper can set the flag to true on debug/test build.
when a test is run the feature flags can be passed as a parameter? ([~accountid:5af5eebc244bc90a10606438] please weight in) so its easy to run a certain test with different feature flags.
feature flags can be set independently on different platforms (ex true for Duvel, false for GOD)
feature flags should be able to set at runtime and should be persistent over reboot
factory reset should clear the feature flags back to the default values
list of feature flags set should be visible in the logs


preferable we can have a very small demo feature behind a feature and a knowledge sharing is given to the other feature teams

fields.description:
Establish a continuous process to review defects (including internal CS0666 defects and Service/PM-CS0444 PQM tickets), ensure each has corresponding test coverage in PractiTest, and automate verification via test scripts—backed by dashboards, alerts, and recurring governance.



Question: 

* It is unclear whether the defect has been adequately covered in *PractiTest* to prevent future *regressions*. Furthermore, we need objective *metrics* or criteria to prioritize test cases when selecting them for *automation*.



This epic operationalizes the *defect coverage lifecycle* by:

* Normalizing defect intake (CS0666 defects + Service/PM PQM CS0444 defects).
* Enforcing *traceability* from defect → PractiTest test case → automation test.
* Building coverage % reporting
* Instituting recurring review/triage to keep coverage and automation current.



h3. Defects Scope

* Defect sources: *high-priority defects (P1 and P2)*
** Internal CS0666 defects: [P1 and P2 with cluster labels.|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/issues?jql=type %3D Defect AND status IN ("In Progress"%2C "In Review"%2C Investigated%2C Reported%2C Resolved%2C "To Be Refined"%2C Verified%2C Closed) AND priority IN ("P1 (Highest)"%2C P2) AND project %3D CS0666 AND labels IN (cluster_Power_Standby%2C cluster_MTR%2C cluster_customer_data%2C cluster_DP_ALT%2C cluster_Pairing%2C cluster_Button%2C cluster_Sharing%2C cluster_production%2C cluster_OOBE%2C cluster_None%2C cluster_Vedett%2C cluster_service_data%2C cluster_Display%2C cluster_IOT%2C cluster_Boot%2C cluster_Update%2C cluster_Narrator%2C rovo-cluster-pairing%2C rovo-cluster-Audio%2C rovo-cluster-Boot%2C rovo-cluster-pair%2C rovo-cluster-Sharing%2C rovo-cluster-Sharing%2C rovo-cluster-Narrator%2C rovo-cluster-FW_Update%2C rovo-cluster-Vedett%2C rovo-cluster-IoT%2C rovo-cluster-Button%2C rovo-cluster-DP_ALT%2C rovo-cluster-Sharing%2C rovo-cluster-share%2C rovo-cluster-Power_Standby%2C rovo-cluster-Update%2C rovo-cluster-Network%2C rovo-cluster-Display%2C rovo-cluster-Customer_Data%2C rovo-cluster-OOBE%2C rovo-cluster_FW_Update%2C rovo-cluster-MTR) ORDER BY created DESC] 
*** Why only focus on the defect with cluster labels (cluster_* and rovo-cluster-*): If we don’t exclude these, there will be thousands of defects, many of which are issues from the early EVK and EVT stages. Reviewing such old items now doesn’t provide much value.



*Continous Monitoring*

* Scanning → Check if the test covered in Practitest → Label → Report
* Coverage tracking in *PractiTest* (cases, URL links).
** If the itrack defect is linked with Practitest already, then automatically add the label 'practitest_covered' to the defect. (The link is from Practitest.)
*** should be able to filter out the tests that is covered in the Practitest.
** If the itrack URL is already in Practitest, then automatically add the label 'practitest_covered' to the defect. (The test already exists.)
** If the test is not in Practitest, then we add the test through the Practitest plugin from the defect itrack.  (Generate the test from the itrack defect, and the URL will be copied to the test case automatically.)



*Increasing Test Automation Rate*

* Prioritize Automation for Critical Defects: The tickets have not been created yet.
** High Priority First (Defect Priority & Test Case Priority) by features.



*Additional details, sourced from* {{2026-01-03}}

{quote}*PractiTest — Session Type Breakdown & Feature Automation Rate Distribution*{quote}

* *Tracked in Jira*

* *Reviewed periodically*
* *Aligned with QA-IN-PLC-00164 SLOs*
* *Documented as part of release artifacts*

fields.description:
h2. What?


atm you have a Duvel and you run trough the OOBE at the end of the OOBE we start MTR as MTR is our only service provider.

If we would support other service providers the OOBE would end with the option to choose MTR or Zoom or webex or ...

 example:

!image-20260112-145706.png|width=290,alt="image-20260112-145706.png"!

With this epic we want to Provide the option to be a Clickshare device. The use cases after selecting this Clickshare service provider will be similar to the wave3 functionality.

This feature should be hidden behind a feature toggle as this should not be released for Duvel for quite some time

|| ||*Duvel*||*GOD*||*Karmeliet (later)*||
|MTR|x| |x|
|Clickshare|x|x|x|
|Zoom (TBD not soon)|x| |x|

as for GOD there is only one option there should not be a selection screen

h2. 
How?

Arch: [~accountid:61eac9f254627a00708d8f57] 
[https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/wovcs/pages/1082064950/Wave+IV+-+Clickshare+Service+Provider|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/wovcs/pages/1082064950/Wave+IV+-+Clickshare+Service+Provider|smart-link] 
When we enable the clickshare service provider we will need to make sure it brings compositor to the foreground so we can share to this.


at the end of this epic we should have a feature toggle which can enable this feature on Duvel (off by default)
once enabled the clickshare service is enabled we should be able to share to it and this should be tested

fields.description:
h3. Purpose

This epic focuses on preparing the required components, base packages and build infrastructure to support Conan V2. It consolidates all technical enablement work needed before product teams can adopt Conan V2 in their build and packaging flows.

h3. Background

The parent epic (CS0100‑5720) defines the global transition to Conan V2. To execute that transition effectively, several foundational elements must be updated or implemented, including Conan profiles, component-level package updates, and CI/CD support in build pipelines. This epic collects all prerequisite activities that make Conan V2 operational in the development and build environment.

h3. Scope

* Create and validate Conan V2 profiles
* Update core base packages (barco‑conan‑base and related packages) to be Conan V2 compliant
* Adapt component packages such as dbus_interfaces, third_party_base, mtk_ta_devkit_base and Debian/Envy packages for Conan V2
* Enable Conan V2 pipelines in cs-bld-jenkins
* Validate package generation through Artifactory under Conan V2
* Investigate and implement Conan V2 lock‑file or debug‑symbol mechanism if required
* Ensure all updated components can be consumed by downstream builds using Conan V2

h3. Out of Scope

* Feature development unrelated to Conan V2
* Organization-wide governance or platform-wide migration strategy (covered in CS0100‑5720)

fields.description:
* RDMA for lowest overload on CPU and PCI, also less impact on total latency
** -RDMA outputs-
*** -RGB 8b-
*** -YUV 422 10b-
** RDMA inputs
*** -Mechanism to first try RDMA when adding a Source-
**** Is this also in action when we assign a new Source via NMOS?
*** -RGB 8b-
*** -YUV 422 10b (still disabled on dev)-
**** Without a lot of conversion and copy delay (Samuel 2nd prio)
* Changeable via NMOS (assign NMOS Sender)
* Barco IO dongles (multiple SRD) (wait on NVIDIA)
* -*PTP leader auto detection (Sven, 1st prio)*-
** We need to validate a changed PTP leader in the network, what do we need to reinit? Or only update the SDP?
* Output support
** -Support Outputs at 60Hz-
** -Support Outputs on lower fps-
* Support changing Lock mode
** UI work
** -Backend, PTP to unlock to input-
*** To be tested better
* 2 frames latency
** -1x 4k60 in and out-
*** On lower than 60Hz, we can’t garantee this yet (NVIDIA mail, NIC uses older frames instead of last)
**** We can’t just send frames to the TX thread in a lower fps, as this will not guarantee the lowest latency (we can’t update the buffer yet when we have a new frame and we see that the previous one is not yet sent and we could have replaced it)
** *2x 4k60 in and out (Toon/Samuel & NVidia, 2nd prio)*
*** RMX chunks not sent and received in time
** 4x 4k60 in and out
* Rivermax sending and receiving is in time
** We know why
* -System Performance optimizations ([https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/TCSW/pages/404587037/Performance#Performance-guide-of-Holoscan|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/TCSW/pages/404587037/Performance#Performance-guide-of-Holoscan|smart-link] )-
** Thread isolation
*** -RMX threads on separate threads-
*** -No system threads on RMX threads-
*** No other application threads on RMX threads
** Jumbo frames?
* *Setup in testroom to test stability for stable release (1st prio, Kristof, Toon stability)*
* *Theatre still working properly*
** First test did not succeed, Sinks are not able to be made, vague RMX error (like always)
** All the system optimizations need to be applied
** -Inputs are working-

fields.description:
* Account cleanup, Account entry process, Account restrictions, Account validations, Account hierarchies, ... 

In Salesforce there are many duplicate accounts being created + there are problems with hierarchies (due to the nature of HC business - with large partners and customers with multi-sites). A structural approach, clear rules and governance is needed. E.g. should service users be able to create new accounts (can this be blocked)? Shouldn't only sales managers be able to create new accounts? How are hierarchies to be built - in case of multi-partner sites for example? Especially in the light of the QAWeb-SF API's (RITM0023918) this could become a bottle neck. And a one-time clean up by the business will not be the answer on the longer term. Thank you for reaching out so we can start up an in-depth discussion on the topic. (Assignment from Dirk Feyants and Mike Sklar (& entire DI Sales management team).

Work breakdown reference - [Identity - CIAM/Salesforce Roadmap - Data Architecture Reference - Confluence|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DAR/pages/1022984400/Identity+-+CIAM+Salesforce+Roadmap]

fields.description:
The Kubernetes community has announced the retirement of Ingress NGINX controller. Best-effort maintenance will continue *until March 2026*. Afterward, there will be no further releases, *no bugfixes, and no updates to resolve any security vulnerabilities* that may be discovered. Existing deployments of Ingress NGINX will continue to function, and installation artifacts will remain available.

We need to find other alternative ingress controller like Gateway API etc and plan for migration.

[+Ingress NGINX Retirement: What You Need to Know | Kubernetes Contributors+|https://www.kubernetes.dev/blog/2025/11/12/ingress-nginx-retirement/]

Identify and refine on below points targeting the migration to new ingress controller:

* how new ingress controller works and the feature set available and where it stands in comparison with Kubernetes nginx
* do all the redirect rules , whitelisting , rate limiting configuration etc works similarly wrt to kubernetes nginx ingress.
* how do cloud provider AKS support with integration..
* support with our tools like external dns ( i think it works with it)
* what controller to select with it .. traffeik, cilium, envoy etc.

Like originally intended, the DI Data Landing zone will not be used for QA Web data consumption in Power BI or other integrations.

The DI Data Landing zone will be used for the database for the old QA Web solution. (See Cloud request for details.) This is more an Infra epic, than a data epic.

As discussed with [~accountid:557058:09f143d1-760f-47e6-9cd9-8243e6dd5652] , the requirement is only for a SQL Server (IaaS) and not for PostgreSQL. Also, the only database to be restored is *qaweb.*

fields.customfield_10011: Applications can address a display in parallel
fields.description:
See [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/qaweb2/pages/123343756/Interaction+between+Agent+and+IWT|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/qaweb2/pages/123343756/Interaction+between+Agent+and+IWT|smart-link] 

h1. Goal

Several DI SW applications need to be able to run gracefully in parallel.

h1. Locking

The goal is that tests and calibration, depending on what they need, acquire a lock at the beginning of their procedure. This is after they have waited for the display to be sufficiently warm.

When they acquire the lock, the lock is kept until the procedure completes. When they fail to get the lock, a specific error needs to be shown:

* For an interactive task, the user gets a dialog indicating the procedure is currently not possible because some other thing is ongoing. The name of the one holding the lock is shown in the dialog box (eg. LRT is currently not possible because SpotView is being used). This is shown in the dialog box and in a task error message to the Portal.
* For a background task: a task error is sent to the Portal. (similar to the above)

h1. SpotView

When the user initiates SpotView, the 2 locks are acquired.

h2. Video lock

In case SpotView fails to acquire the video lock, it shows a message to the user “SpotView cannot run when … is running.”

h2. Backlight lock

In case SpotView tries to acquire the lock, but fails, it boosts the luminance nevertheless. It does create an InvalidationNotice which indicates to the ongoing test that the display it is working on has changing, invalidating the ongoing test.

h1. Risks ⚠️

* We have chosen [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/1DI/pages/777422670/DI+Applications+can+address+Barco+displays+in+parallel#Solution-2|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/1DI/pages/777422670/DI+Applications+can+address+Barco+displays+in+parallel#Solution-2|smart-link] as the solution for the stories listed here, because it could pose a risk that many aspects of the solution might change and require more time and attention than expected.

comments.body: what is the list of supported resolutions? [~accountid:557058:5c061ae6-cca4-4531-b7c7-5648da07ddbf]

[~accountid:712020:9e597d9b-460c-4348-b227-a0fe3562220e] media team to propose a list of supported resolutions for review & acceptance [~accountid:61fb7f92e688d6007069c9bf] [~accountid:712020:e68dad5b-8820-4e63-bda9-a9e046b8c5f1]

I assume Media has to 

* provide a list of output resolutions
* make sure we have component-level testing for those resolutions

which can be a bit of work if we have to change the setups to accommodate for this

Ranked with [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-3858|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-3858|smart-link]  

* As per prod backlog discussion on {{2024-12-09}} , the two epics need to finish in tandem.

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] , FYI, Important for the OpSpace migration.
best to have this from the get-go. As you don’t want to tighten this afterwards.

[~accountid:63d7859cfb75f8568f5e8da4] I doubt if this is the good approach. It would exclude migration of projects that use the 5K resolution with the OPS-220.

This problem will solve itself with the introduction of a SAN-060, fit for contemporary display resolutions. In the meantime OPS-220 will remain supported. So instead of curtailing an existing product, I propose to opt for the way forward and fix this in Barco CTRL.

To be defined if this same principle applies to the 2x 4K on NDN-220 feature which was introduced with OpSpace 1.9.5.

!image-20250114-180308.png|width=1329,height=750,alt="image-20250114-180308.png"!

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] not sure I understand your comment.
An OPS-220 in OpSpace that supports 5K wide out, will after migration to CTRL still support 5K out, why would it not ?

The output resolution “regression” manifests itself for new Barco CTRL sales which are by defaul with a SAN-050, which cannot support 5120 x 2160 or 5120 x 2880 *@ 60fps* due to the HDMI 2.0 limits (details here: [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GEAX/pages/445022286/Barco+CTRL+Video+Timing+Overview|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GEAX/pages/445022286/Barco+CTRL+Video+Timing+Overview|smart-link]  ), whereas OpSpace with an OPS-220 _can_ support such video timing.

The Barco CTRL features & specs [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GEAX/pages/174006438/Barco+CTRL+Features+Specifications|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GEAX/pages/174006438/Barco+CTRL+Features+Specifications|smart-link]  list the video timings supported per the number of displays connected per SAN-050, garantueeing decoding specs.
For 2 times 4K, 2 SAN-050 would be required. Which needs more network/cabling, but is less expensive/smaller than OPS-220.

[~accountid:557058:5c061ae6-cca4-4531-b7c7-5648da07ddbf]I agree. The OPS-220 spec cannot be reduced. This post was to raise this point as an alternative would have been to drop the OPS-220 specs to what a SAN-050 can reach. The title of this epic alludes to this behaviour.

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] the epic was purposfully written with a vision of multiple SAN flavours, each with their distinct capabilities, in mind.

The epic title and its description states SAN, not SAN-050. While subtle, it means the enforced restrictions align with the SAN model.
(an OPS-220 coming from an OpSpace migration into CTRL, will still be called OPS-220 as that is what the box is labelled like, but in CTRL system context it in essence becomes a SAN and behaves like one)

Perhaps this needs to be made more explicit.


Now, a trick question: after the CTRL version is released where the OpSpce migration is announced a supported, there is a new CTRL sale requiring 5120 x 2160, and we still have only SAN-050 in portfolio, what will happen ? 😉

[~accountid:557058:5c061ae6-cca4-4531-b7c7-5648da07ddbf] - Wow, this is a nuance I did not catch. Thanks for clarifying.
I have a hard time figuring out what people have built with OpSpace in the field. No telemetry and no restrictions. So indeed, this will be of great help and not only for the CTRL to ??? migration in some distant future 👾 . 

I have no idea what requests for 5120x2160 will trigger 😃 .

UX task added to the Epic. [~accountid:61fb7f9bb3ec760068c222e7] , [~accountid:557058:d62807bc-ead8-4dd3-a387-0d271329117c] , please update Arch story points in conetxt of additional UX work to be done as part of Epic.
[~accountid:640f05acb05b4e3e7da841d8]  Increased story points from 3 to 7. I''l put it on the agenda of the next Arch guild meeting for confirmation

[~accountid:640f05acb05b4e3e7da841d8] why is this linked to OPS_Migration ?

If CTRL does *not* enforce limiting desk creation to supported SAN resolutions, we can still migrate. Or what am I missing here ?

Perhaps OpSpace has such enforcement, and it was missed in the feature parity overview: [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GEAX/pages/90279470/Barco+CTRL+feature+parity+with+OpSpace|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GEAX/pages/90279470/Barco+CTRL+feature+parity+with+OpSpace|smart-link] 
in which case I would understand it gets labelled with “OpSpace_parity” but not with “OPS_Migration”

[~accountid:557058:5c061ae6-cca4-4531-b7c7-5648da07ddbf]Opspace does not enforce this. Also, in migration scenarios, a migrated OPS-220 still needs to support the valid DP resolutions it does in OpSpace today. The current SAN hardware limitations cannot affect OpSpace as it is today.

If OpSpace does not enforce this, then

* implementation of this epic in CTRL is neither needed for doing OpSpace migration neither for OpSpace parity
* the (including opspace devices) part that was added in the title can be removed
* it only serves to improve the CTRL installation UX & robustness

Because:

* an OpSpace that runs OPS-1xx/2xx devices
* got its desk configured with resolution xyz
* where resolution xyz is not enforced upon config time

will after migration to CTRL sw

* run CTRL sw on OPS-1xx/2xx
* will still support the same desk resolution xyz
* there is no need to have any resolution enforcement in CTRL to achieve the migration (on the contrary, I would say)

Ah wait, “my euro has fallen”. 

Implementation of this epic is not needed to be able to migrate, but when we implement it and the full installed field base of OpSpace is not migrated yet, we need to make sure its implementation is not resticted to SAN-050 only and does not *break* the migration ! That explains why the OPS_Migration label got added.

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] [~accountid:640f05bf57f0c028e2f3ecf4] 

As shown in the System Review today, the design is ready to enforce the limitations of a SAN during creation/edit of a wall or desk. However, [~accountid:63d782a61b13d42998e06144] had an important remark: How do we need to handle existing setups of customers, that currently exceed the supported resolution of a SAN? This is currently not mentioned in the epic. 

[~accountid:557058:15d1e6d2-9c28-4c1a-b38d-1fa29dcc61bd]

[~accountid:63d785418978d7a435382f48] If the combination of resolution and number of used outputs is not supported, then this can be fixed by adding SAN hardware. That is important as that means there is a solution.

Barco CTRL will get strict on enforcing supported combinations That implies that Barco CTRL was not strict before and hence silently allowed configuring non-supported combinations.

Hence, a new firmware cannot just trash existing installations. Release notes are not sufficient to warn for such an occasion.

Proposal:

* For all configurations that are not compliant: Show a clear warning that these can lead to performance issues and are not supported.
* If a non-compliant desk would need to be reconfigured, what to do? Allow the reconfiguring of the desk or block it. In the former case the warning would not be blocking the wrong configuration.

Question: Is it OK to only warn for a non-supported configuration in all cases or should it just be blocked. As a customer, seeing such warning would make me feel uncomfortable enough to fix the setup. Advantage, foreseeing extra SAN hardware and the related power and network cabling can be done within a reasonable timeframe, not leading to a broking configuration.

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] 

A prototype example with the described warning behavior: [https://www.figma.com/proto/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD%2FRPC-wall-and-desk?page-id=5%3A10&node-id=6662-26334&viewport=-716%2C-6146%2C0.18&t=qHreDWbESdOqo97r-1&scaling=scale-down&content-scaling=fixed&starting-point-node-id=68%3A29387|https://www.figma.com/proto/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD%2FRPC-wall-and-desk?page-id=5%3A10&node-id=6662-26334&viewport=-716%2C-6146%2C0.18&t=qHreDWbESdOqo97r-1&scaling=scale-down&content-scaling=fixed&starting-point-node-id=68%3A29387|smart-link] 

In the example, there is a wall that was configured with an unsupported timing on the SAN-050 before upgrading to the latest version. This wall is now flagged with a warning state but still works just like before the upgrade. If the user goes into the edit flow, a strict enforcement takes place just like during creation of a wall. At this point the user can either:

#  Lower the resolution of the SAN-050
# Unassign some outputs and reassign the outputs to the added hardware after recabling
# Close their browser or enter a different URL and end up with an incomplete setup of their wall, which means the Barco Logo will be shown on the wall with the awaiting configuration message.

[~accountid:63d785418978d7a435382f48] 

The warning is ok but next to that, the customer must be able to exit the edit mode without breaking an operational wall. These systems are installed in critical environments. Barco must consider the impact of such destructive behavior in this context. There needs to be time to correct this situation which results from Barco failing to impose restrictions. Customers should not be the ones punished because of this situation. Note that the wording might be harsh but that’s probably because I just spent three days with customers…

[~accountid:63d785418978d7a435382f48], I reached out to [~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] and he agrees with the enforcement you propose.
His concern is the fact that when you click on the “edit setup“ to find out what is not supported, the desk is immediately broken without a way to go back.
This is especially troublesome when a desk is being used.

Changing the warning message to "Unsupported output configuration" and/or redirecting the user first to desk/wall details could help.

These concerns are actually caused by other unresolved tickets and not the proposed enforcement itself:
[https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-10036|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-10036|smart-link]
[https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-10534|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-10534|smart-link]

[~accountid:557058:15d1e6d2-9c28-4c1a-b38d-1fa29dcc61bd] You described the situation very well. As a rule of thumb, the product must act in a way that if an admin still manages to break something, the sentiment is: 

{quote}Oh, stupid me, I’ve been clearly warned by the system and still pushed through. Will do better next time.{quote}

We should use the correct terminology to avoid implementation mistakes.
resolution 1920x1080
timing 1920x1080@60
Assigned to Juniper team as discussed during product backlog handover on {{2025-07-03}}
Hi [~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] , Can we have the specification sheet with a list of supported output timings of OPS decoder devices, for each of the output combinations?

As aligned with [~accountid:557058:d62807bc-ead8-4dd3-a387-0d271329117c], the required API changes for this epic will be done in Curium. 
cc [~accountid:61eacb0a09633b0069e83451] [~accountid:640f05acb05b4e3e7da841d8]

Hi [~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] , [~accountid:557058:d62807bc-ead8-4dd3-a387-0d271329117c], [~accountid:61fb7f9bb3ec760068c222e7] . Can you please provide us the approved list of supported resolutions for OPS and SAN devices (with  number of mapped port considerations). 

cc [~accountid:640f05acb05b4e3e7da841d8] [~accountid:61eacb0a09633b0069e83451]

As per discussion on {{2025-08-05}}  with [~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] , [~accountid:61fb7f9bb3ec760068c222e7] , [~accountid:615aa5729cdb93007267f6e4] , following has been agreed as fit criteria update:

(-) -a specification is delivered with a list of supported SAN output timing, for each of the output combinations: one output, two outputs, there outputs, four outputs-

* -the specification shall at least cover, but not be limited to, what the NGS-D440 supports as timing at its 2 inputs-

(-) -this timing list is covered by TA to ensure the specification never regresses-

(-) in CTRLsystem, the create wall/desk flow takes the supported SAN output timing list into account and only allows to create walls & desks with a supported resolution combination

* This resolution shall be based on a formula that allows maximum possible resolution @ 60fps as a boundary codition. 
* Any resolution within the boundary shall be allowed.
* The resolution not specifically tested, but within boundary will be supported on best effort basis only.

This has been done to allow for a wider range of resolutions to be aceptable as the specification sheet is not exhaustive and it is not feasible to validate each resultion at the media layer. Also, not allowing a range within maximum supported resoluition blocks the value to be added with forced EDID epic [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-13610|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-13610|smart-link] 

cc: [~accountid:557058:5c061ae6-cca4-4531-b7c7-5648da07ddbf] , [~accountid:640f05bf57f0c028e2f3ecf4] , [~accountid:63d7859cfb75f8568f5e8da4] , [~accountid:63d784a78978d7a435382ebc] , [~accountid:640f05b90e6828ab2023d74b]

As per team refinment, the Epic will be delivered in 2 contigous slices viz, For Desk and followed by For Wall.

cc: [~accountid:557058:5c061ae6-cca4-4531-b7c7-5648da07ddbf] [~accountid:61eacb0a09633b0069e83451] [~accountid:640f05b90e6828ab2023d74b]

[~accountid:63d784a78978d7a435382ebc] [~accountid:640f05b90e6828ab2023d74b] 

As discussed, some updates to the inital prototype and documentation:

1. If the user attempts to assign an output that exceeds the device's timing limitations, the *error is only triggered when selecting a suggestion panel on the canvas*—not when choosing the output from the device list below the canvas.

* [Updated prototype - LCD/RPC wall|https://www.figma.com/proto/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD-RPC-wall-and-desk?page-id=5%3A10&node-id=6361-38484&viewport=673%2C-8907%2C0.26&t=jcKB7GjpUm4bCr4j-1&scaling=scale-down&content-scaling=fixed&starting-point-node-id=68%3A29387]
* [Updated prototype - Desk|https://www.figma.com/proto/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD-RPC-wall-and-desk?page-id=5%3A10&node-id=6373-48685&viewport=673%2C-8907%2C0.26&t=jcKB7GjpUm4bCr4j-1&scaling=scale-down&content-scaling=fixed&starting-point-node-id=68%3A29387]
* [Updated documentation - LCD/RPC Wall example|https://www.figma.com/design/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD-RPC-wall-and-desk?node-id=6487-15482&t=VeEbRrs6clG3wJFc-4]
* [Updated documentation - LED Wall example|https://www.figma.com/design/KcQN8hnUhchpd3cjXr8msU/3.2-CTRLsystem---LED-wall-and-loop-through?node-id=9553-49132&t=1hWF6YIGPTP62Gkq-4]
* [Updated documentation - Desk example|https://www.figma.com/design/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD-RPC-wall-and-desk?node-id=6487-46090&t=VeEbRrs6clG3wJFc-4]

This behavior is different from the existing enforcement behavior: L-shaped LED output, only 1 loop-through output, loop-through geometry mismatch, HD out licenses. The reasons to deviate from the previous behavior: 

* Device selection is a more frequent operation compared to output mapping, and triggering the validation on device selection will lead to a lot of *unnecessary validation* calls being triggered from Proxima.
* Along with Proxima, we also *need to protect our APIs* so that an API client cannot create a workplace that exceeds the supported timing. Having the validation call within the Place/Add Display APIS will protect both Proxima and API clients from a single entry point. Otherwise, we need to duplicate the logic on FE and BE.
* Triggering the validation calls directly from FE will introduce a number of new branches/scenarios in the code that *will increase the maintainability* of the Canvas (which is overly-complex already).



2.  If the preferred timing of a device’s first output exceeds its supported limit, *the timing is automatically lowered to the highest value the device can handle for that output*.

* [Updated documentation - LCD/RPC Wall and Desk|https://www.figma.com/design/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD-RPC-wall-and-desk?node-id=8205-54678&t=VeEbRrs6clG3wJFc-4]
* [Updated documentation - LED Wall|https://www.figma.com/design/KcQN8hnUhchpd3cjXr8msU/3.2-CTRLsystem---LED-wall-and-loop-through?node-id=11894-157620&t=1hWF6YIGPTP62Gkq-4]

[~accountid:63d784a78978d7a435382ebc] [~accountid:640f05b90e6828ab2023d74b] 

As discussed: 

* Added a warning message in case the connected outputs already exceed the device’s timing limitations, but the user hasn’t yet attempted to assign an output that would trigger the error.
** [+Updated documentation - LCD/RPC Wall and Desk+|https://www.figma.com/design/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD-RPC-wall-and-desk?node-id=8391-48991&t=9Fd3tfmLFro382JF-4]
** [Updated documentation - LED Wall|https://www.figma.com/design/KcQN8hnUhchpd3cjXr8msU/3.2-CTRLsystem---LED-wall-and-loop-through?node-id=12008-177874&t=mdSo725gtcVU9xXY-4]
* Added feedback with an info message when the timing is automatically lowered because the preferred timing of a device’s first output exceeds its supported limit. 
** [Prototype example|https://www.figma.com/proto/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD-RPC-wall-and-desk?page-id=5%3A10&node-id=8391-33639&viewport=952%2C-8827%2C0.24&t=bPRizM8Cei9d1Rau-1&scaling=scale-down&content-scaling=fixed&starting-point-node-id=68%3A29387]

fields.description:
+*Business Value*+

As part of ensuring a Barco CTRLsystem, works as intended, we want to ensure only desks can be created with displays with timing that are supported by the SAN/ OPS output.

+*Fit Criteria*+

(-) -a specification is delivered with a list of supported SAN output timing, for each of the output combinations: one output, two outputs, there outputs, four outputs-

* -the specification shall at least cover, but not be limited to, what the NGS-D440 supports as timing at its 2 inputs-

(-) -this timing list is covered by TA to ensure the specification never regresses-

(-) in CTRLsystem, the create desk flow takes the supported SAN output timing list into account and only allows to create walls & desks with a supported resolution combination

* This resolution shall be based on a formula that allows maximum possible resolution @ 60fps as a boundary codition. The formula and timing details are available in [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-27052|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-27052|smart-link] 
* Any resolution within the boundary shall be allowed.
* The resolution not specifically tested, but within boundary will be supported on best effort basis only.

(-)  in case a desk is being made with an unsupported timing combination, then the user cannot create the desk, and a feedback message is provided why this is not possible, and what can be done about it  

(-)  in case a desk exists with an unsupported timing combination, then the  feedback message is provided on desk list. And user cannot edit the desk, unless it now has supported timing.

+*Figma links*+

* [Figma link: Create LCD/RPC wall prototype|https://www.figma.com/proto/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD%2FRPC-wall-and-desk?page-id=5%3A10&node-id=6361-38484&viewport=764%2C-1840%2C0.19&t=IS5c10bmG4PobgM1-1&scaling=scale-down&content-scaling=fixed&starting-point-node-id=68%3A29387]
* [Figma link: Create desk prototype|https://www.figma.com/proto/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD%2FRPC-wall-and-desk?page-id=5%3A10&node-id=6373-48685&viewport=764%2C-1840%2C0.19&t=IS5c10bmG4PobgM1-1&scaling=scale-down&content-scaling=fixed&starting-point-node-id=68%3A29387]
* [Figma link:  Edit LCD/RPC wall prototype - Existing setup|https://www.figma.com/proto/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD%2FRPC-wall-and-desk?page-id=5%3A10&node-id=6662-26334&viewport=1304%2C-13615%2C0.38&t=osKIFq9Vw8anG9Vm-1&scaling=scale-down&content-scaling=fixed&starting-point-node-id=68%3A29387]
* [Figma link: LCD/RPC wall and desk documentation|https://www.figma.com/design/IId5ypCrwB6TtljU96tI3L/3.1-CTRLsystem---Create-LCD%2FRPC-wall-and-desk?node-id=6487-15493&t=JTXvisXdSNfiSS26-4]
* [Figma link: LED wall documentation|https://www.figma.com/design/KcQN8hnUhchpd3cjXr8msU/3.2-CTRLsystem---LED-wall-and-loop-through?node-id=9553-49162&t=A0mlD5YBuaxjKtmm-4]
* [Figma link: Wall and Desk overview - Documentation|https://www.figma.com/design/6wHEgpFKnpD8lnLDgBHbjc/3.0-CTRLsystem---Wall-and-desk-overview?node-id=3643-31246&t=DN9RvUv1xvLu9HiD-4]
* [Figma link: Wall and Desk overview - Combination with other states documentation|https://www.figma.com/design/6wHEgpFKnpD8lnLDgBHbjc/3.0-CTRLsystem---Wall-and-desk-overview?node-id=3643-31598&t=DN9RvUv1xvLu9HiD-4]





{panel:bgColor=#deebff}
*Security Design Review:* [~accountid:712020:e059e4aa-65e1-4218-aabc-6970656f34ef]

cc: [~accountid:712020:e7d31fd3-7f23-4a89-b826-ad17642a3886] [~accountid:712020:b33591a5-091a-4dca-bf26-45330ee93b71]

As discussed with [~accountid:640f05b90e6828ab2023d74b] about the changes in SAN output timing it is found that no security obligation is there for now basis on below points:

* The system will only allow wall and desk creation with supported SAN output timings, based on a maximum resolution supported at 60fps and unsupported timing combinations will prevent wall/desk creation, with warning message to the user. The system notifies users of unsupported timings in two main ways:-
** - *During wall/desk creation:* If a user attempts to create a wall or desk with an unsupported timing combination, the system prevents the creation and provides a feedback message explaining why it is not possible and what can be done about it.
** - *For existing walls:* If a wall exists with an unsupported timing combination, a feedback message is shown in the wall list, and the user cannot edit the wall unless it now has a supported timing.
* The same API used for validating SAN output timing in *Walls* is also used for *Desks*. If the timing is exceeded, the system will either display a warning message to the user or *automatically lower the timing to the highest value supported by the device for that output.*
* Security posture is intact since we are using the same API for both Walls and Desks to validate SAN output timings.

Ref Wall Epic: [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-27413|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-27413|smart-link] 

{color:#97A0AF}*[ SECURITY ]*{color} {color:#36B37E}*[ OK ]*{color}
{panel}



Note: We will be allowing all timings listed in the *Feature and Specification Sheet* for the decoders ([https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GEAX/pages/174006438/Barco+CTRL+Features+Specifications|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GEAX/pages/174006438/Barco+CTRL+Features+Specifications|smart-link] ), as these have been validated and are within the device's maximum capability. Additionally, a few extra timings—also within the device's maximum threshold—may be supported, even if they are not explicitly listed.

fields.customfield_10011: [CTRL] filter selected devices and date/time for support file
fields.description:
+*Current Situation*+

SAN-050 log files are much bigger then NGS-D440 log files.

In Barco CTRL, if a lot of SAN-050 devices are added, the support file might become very big.

Not only impractical to handle, it might even grow beyond the size the support file service might be able to handle, jeopardizing stability of the system.

 Today there's a workaround for this: Download the CTRL system sypport file without device log files, and then download the support file of each device individually.

+*Fit Criteria*+

(-) Extend CTRLsystem functionality to allow downloading support file of a selected set of walls/desks/ encoder sources

(-) Within selected Wall/Desks, all applicable (SAN) devices are downlaoded.

(-) SAS logs are always included

(-) Naming convention of downlaoded files should be human readable to provide context on downlaoded log file

(-) Support file creation progress banner is on the top of the screen to give feedback to the user even when user navigates away from download screen.

(-) If a download is in progress, attempt to download again by same or other users gives user feedback on in-progress download.



+*General requirements*+

(-) use cases are added to PTC test management tool

(-) for each use case, an automated test exists and is run as part of at least one build job and delivers a valid result

(-) regression testing has been done, follow-up issues are created and aligned with SystemPO if regressions are accepted

(-) security testing has been done

(-) explorative testing is done and follow-up issues are created if needed



+*Out of Scope:*+

* Refactor maintenence screen to allow downloading support file by device usage type (wall/ desk/encoder/ gateway)Pop up window to list selected wall/desk/encoder source support files being downloaded
* Ability to downlaod all encoders/ Gateways when downloading wall/ desk/ sources support files
* User is able to provide a small text message as part of logs download.
* Restricting download beyond reasonable permissible number of devices logs.  
* User is able to provide a small text message as part of logs download.
*  maximum number of SAN devices that can be added to 1 support file = qty 25. 
** This number will change based on combination of SAN and encoders to be downloaded. An optimum number to be achieved to replace 1 SAN with x encoder files.
** a human will not manually correlate supprt files of many devices at once, hence a hard maximum of qty25 should suffice
** if an admin attempts to select more devices, CTLRsystem will prevent this
* 

This Epic is slice 1 for overall augmentation of Downlaod support files, the other Epics being:

* Outcome of [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-20207|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-20207|smart-link] 
* [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-7157|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-7157|smart-link] 







*See*

UX [https://www.figma.com/proto/5JtarokVH8rO9wlRP8yu9K/1.5-CTRLsystem---System-support-file?node-id=245-49883&viewport=184%2C350%2C0.1&t=lAeMYMQ0bmZQMhxz-0&scaling=min-zoom&starting-point-node-id=245%3A49883|https://www.figma.com/proto/5JtarokVH8rO9wlRP8yu9K/1.5-CTRLsystem---System-support-file?node-id=245-49883&viewport=184%2C350%2C0.1&t=lAeMYMQ0bmZQMhxz-0&scaling=min-zoom&starting-point-node-id=245%3A49883|smart-link]

High level sizing by team:

* Thumbnail service changes to deal with large (target 1000) encoders with thumbnails
* Cygnus changes for tubmanil service implementation
* UI changes to restrict wall for 200 FHD

Size ~ 13 (can be higher as some unknowns exist) SP

For FPL project in the US (~5M$)  there is a requirement to support a videowall of 42x5 = *210FHD* panels (55 decoders). The go live is June 2026.
[~accountid:640f05acb05b4e3e7da841d8]; please update the criteria to support a wall size of at least 210FHD panels.

!image-20251126-135638.png|width=1414,alt="image-20251126-135638.png"!

fields.description:
+*Business Request*+

* Current (CTRL 1.11) specifications allow for a wall up to 100 Full HD panels overall (limited 40 by 10), but upcoming projects require larger walls, -such as 37 by 3 and 33 by 5 configurations.-
* specific business requests for larger walls, which cannot be split into multiple walls as per the client's requirementincluding a 
** 210 (42*5, 55 decoders) panel wall for FPL in US. This is a ~5MN USD oppurtunity, required by Q2 2026. We target to support upto 250 for this use case to allow for some scaling, if required at customer end.
** -159-panel wall for a project in Saudi Arabia.-
* *The target for a large wall support is 400 panels (agnostic of resolution or size or SAS version)*

As part of the easy UX paradigm, the product must offer an intuitive & delighful UX flow for creation of a large wall

+*Fit Criteria*+

(-) can create an LCD/RPC wall 

* Max overall 250 panels atleast (agnostic of resolution or size) per wall. 
* Target upto 400 panels (if feasible).
* maxi 10 panels high
* Increase max panels to 50 wide (from current 40, to allow for 42 panels request, with some room to scale)

(-)  the create large wall flow shall be intuitive IAW UX design

(-)  The create wall creation flow should not slow down in case of Large wall

(-)  Whenever user types more then  50 columns and 10 rows (limited by 250 overall panels, 400 if feasible)  then it automatically reverts to 50 and 10 which is the max limit , however, user does not get any message

(-)  Test-driven specification to determine the performance limits of large walls with many virtual encoders.

* Test for 800 encoders, making up 200 compositions, 4 AV source per compoistion and all compositions to be used on wall
** Possible constraints on CTRLwall source tray or canvas may be encountered
** Test where system becomes unusable for the customer
** Try to optimize (or flag if its big work)
** Update system specifications

(-)   Snap to grid functionalityneed to be intuitive for a large wall(250 panels, upto 400 if feasible). It is tough for user to make a source fit in a specific grid, 

+*General requirements*+

(-) use cases are added to PTC test management tool

(-) for each use case, an automated test exists and is run as part of at least one build job and delivers a valid result

(-) regression testing has been done, follow-up issues are created and aligned with SystemPO if regressions are accepted

(-) security testing has been done

(-) explorative testing is done and follow-up issues are created if needed

comments.body:
First Kick-off session regarding this Epic was recorded and could be seen following this link:

[ENAIRE - Federation Sync feature Refinement-20250304_163703-Meeting Recording.mp4|https://barcozone-my.sharepoint.com/:v:/r/personal/ibrahim_abene_barco_com/Documents/Recordings/ENAIRE%20-%20Federation%20Sync%20feature%20Refinement-20250304_163703-Meeting%20Recording.mp4?csf=1&web=1&e=BRJBgu&nav=eyJyZWZlcnJhbEluZm8iOnsicmVmZXJyYWxBcHAiOiJTdHJlYW1XZWJBcHAiLCJyZWZlcnJhbFZpZXciOiJTaGFyZURpYWxvZy1MaW5rIiwicmVmZXJyYWxBcHBQbGF0Zm9ybSI6IldlYiIsInJlZmVycmFsTW9kZSI6InZpZXcifX0%3D]

# Should personal sources (Web and RDP) be included in the scope?

*_[TR>] A question for the market to answer ->_* [~accountid:640f05bf57f0c028e2f3ecf4] 

# Should user management and attributes sync (including source permissions) for both LDAP and local be included?

*_[TR>] Local is under our control. Barco can decide without much external influence._*

*_LDAP is different as we do not know their LDAP infrastructure. Does every site has their own IDP or is there always a central IDP. When multiple IDPs are in use, then a sync is probably not desired._*

# Will the sync be one-way (local to master) or two-way (local to master to local)?

*_[TR>] In OpSpace this is two-way. I prefer to not have a master – local relation but have siblings . That is more flexible. The master-local concept can be implemented based on ABAC._*

# Should compositions (for Wall) be included in the sync?

*_[TR>] A question for the market to answer ->_* [~accountid:640f05bf57f0c028e2f3ecf4]

Short discussion with [~accountid:640f05bf57f0c028e2f3ecf4] [~accountid:63d7856e1b13d42998e062fd] 
Proposal for fit criteria:


No master, all systems are peers (or siblings)


* Sources
** Only sources are synced, but all type of sources
** application certificate CA are put in the trust store of all other federated systems (so all SAN-050s and NGS-D440s have a mutual trust)
** Encoder sources will only work when multicast routing is correctly setup and all systems are in a different multicast range.
** RDP and Common Web will use the gateway from the system where the source is defined. If that system is down, the source cannot be opened.
** Can sources in different systems have the same name? Can they be renamed on syncing? Or are they “namespaced” ????
* Users:
** Local users are not synced
** LDAP users are not synced, even when they connect to the same (or synced) AD.
** Roles (Admin/Operator) are per system. A person which is administrator across systems will need to be made Admin in each individual system
* Attributes:
** Attributes are not synced.
** Attributes with the same name, but from different systems are considered different attribute (like in a different name space)
* Source permissions:
** source permissions are not synced (as users and groups are different instances even when connected to the same LDAP) they are useless anyway
** If a certain group of operators are able to work at different locations, their source permissions need to be added on both systems.
* Layouts & perspectives:
** not synced
** no follow-me (or maybe later???)
* Compositions
** Nice to have


If we can agree to limit it to the above scope, this would already reduce the amount effort.

[~accountid:640f05bf57f0c028e2f3ecf4] [~accountid:63d7856e1b13d42998e062fd] [~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] 
Can you agree to start with the above? Then we can do a first round of refinement to look at feasibility whether other limitations or pitfalls are raised.

[~accountid:61fb7f9bb3ec760068c222e7]Support for all sources is a major improvement compared to OpSpace.

Are encoders accessible from a federated node (better name?) in case the node that manages the encoders is down? I think so. This is a specific requirement for Enaire and other projects that use federation to increase uptime of their environment.

For RDP and common web, the dependency on their node is OK. These sources can be accessed directly if that is required.

The other sync/non-sync decisions mainly relate to configuration, not operation. Non-sync is more configuration work but also allows for different configurations across nodes.

[~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] 

{quote}Are encoders accessible from a federated node (better name?) in case the node that manages the encoders is down? I think so.{quote}

This is possible, but some extra work.
This assumes that the encoder doesn’t change IP address while the server is down. We can cache the IP addresses of encoders of the remote system in the DNS of the local system.
We could even go for a more general solution where device’s IP addresses are getting cached in all devices.

For RDP and common web, the dependency on their node is OK. These sources can be accessed directly if that is required.

For common RDP, this is not true. “Proxy runs on the gateway from the system where the source is defined“ is done on purpose to avoid that an RDP Proxy would open a session which closes the session of another RDP Proxy connecting to the same RDP server session.

[~accountid:61fb7f9bb3ec760068c222e7]Right, but for critical RDP sources, backup sources could be prepared on the local system that point to the same RDP host and use the gateway of the local system. These can only be used in case of emergency to avoid the conflicts you mention. This can be documented in the disaster recovery procedures of the sites.

Agreed.
The RDP anti-ping-pong logic (stop automatic relogin when thrown out) needs to be implemented. But I think this was already foreseen.

Regarding encoder access in case of a dead server cluster. Is my understanding correct that the SAS acts as a DNS server to point a decoder to the encoder based on its FQDN? Does an encoder that gets a new IP address from the DHCP server inform the SAS that the DNS record must be updated? In that case, a way to solve the issue is that if the encoder cannot reach it server, it tries a second server (as present in its trust store). That would require a dynamic synchronization mechanism between the nodes in a federation. 

Related question: In a single cluster setup: If an encoder receives a new IP address while the cluster is down, does the encoder report its new address once the server is online again? This is important in the context of having self-healing / recovering systems.

As discussed in refinement meeting on {{2025-03-25}} Epic split to [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-24848|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-24848|smart-link]  to cover user federation.

cc: [~accountid:61fb7f9bb3ec760068c222e7] [~accountid:557058:d62807bc-ead8-4dd3-a387-0d271329117c] [~accountid:640f05bf57f0c028e2f3ecf4] [~accountid:557058:15d1e6d2-9c28-4c1a-b38d-1fa29dcc61bd] [~accountid:63d7859cfb75f8568f5e8da4] [~accountid:712020:a95f6402-65e9-4532-9c4c-72821fb12033]

My meeting notes of {{2025-03-25}} 


* Systems might be on a different CTRL version (both versions within the support window of STS/LTS)
* Namespacing for source names. Duplicate source names can exist in different systems. When shownin UI, prefixed with namespace.
* federation permission
** attribute based source groups to allow sharing a source to a specific system
* Maximum number of sources/devices. Same specifications as single system, but:
** total number of sources => sum of local and all sources shared with this system
** total number of devices => only local devices are counted
* License for activating federation.
** License to share sources to another system
** Licence to see shared sources from another system
** Or do both CTRL systems need a license to share in both directions?

[~accountid:61fb7f9bb3ec760068c222e7]

When only prefixing, names could become long or are not relevant because the clusters do not represent physical entities relevant to the operator. One control room could have two clusters to reduce dependencies. Also, the prefix must be configurable in order to be relevant to the user. The FQDN typically has to comply with strickt IT naming conventions which are likely obscur to an operator. 

I propose to offer different representations of federated sources:

Source list element in CTRLsystem, CTRLwall and Desk UI:

* No distinction, name only 
* Hierarchical grouping/tree view
* Columns
* Prefix + Name

Window title / Source label

* Prefixed + Name
* Name only i.e E17 HM234E is an already unique name of a camera along highway E17 at hectometer 234 looking Direction East.

Source federation allocated to Juniper and Sirius teams, after discussed with all interested teams.

[~accountid:557058:d62807bc-ead8-4dd3-a387-0d271329117c] ENAIRE is an existing customer using OpSpace across multiple of their remote and central Air Traffic Control (ATC) centers. Each center has its dedicated OpSpace system and sources are available across these systems.

[~accountid:557058:5c061ae6-cca4-4531-b7c7-5648da07ddbf] , [~accountid:640f05bf57f0c028e2f3ecf4] , [~accountid:5af5ecb79e3ea106fafab07f] , [~accountid:557058:d62807bc-ead8-4dd3-a387-0d271329117c] , [~accountid:61fb7f9bb3ec760068c222e7] , [~accountid:63d7859cfb75f8568f5e8da4] , [~accountid:712020:e059e4aa-65e1-4218-aabc-6970656f34ef] [~accountid:712020:e97ae198-663c-4453-8552-ca5851293c75] , [~accountid:557058:15d1e6d2-9c28-4c1a-b38d-1fa29dcc61bd] , [~accountid:61eacb0a09633b0069e83451] , [~accountid:63d783bcf1475ad42c575aee] , [~accountid:557058:85b9f1e1-a89e-4572-99ed-838906d54129] , [~accountid:712020:8b3227a8-de06-456d-a6e1-f6507b7e0867] , [~accountid:712020:a95f6402-65e9-4532-9c4c-72821fb12033]

fields.description:
+*Use case and Business/customer value*+

About EANIARE: ENAIRE is the main provider of air navigation and aeronautical information services in Spain, the fourth in Europe by traffic volume, and one of the most important in the world

EASA ([https://www.easa.europa.eu/en|https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.easa.europa.eu%2Fen&data=05%7C02%7CHimanshu.Jain%40barco.com%7C0b957231a420463ab2dd08dd5a527fef%7Caeb84c9162704446ada5d71ceba1d535%7C1%7C0%7C638766032558636191%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJFbXB0eU1hcGkiOnRydWUsIlYiOiIwLjAuMDAwMCIsIlAiOiJXaW4zMiIsIkFOIjoiTWFpbCIsIldUIjoyfQ%3D%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=SKcrqWp51fwzvCpUKTHmlBSASDXU0FxTVO%2FVj3MmkY8%3D&reserved=0]) forces Enaire to ensure all the systems being used are equipped with high availability covering all possible use scenarios

* *Control Room and Tower Management:* Setup of multiple control rooms and airport towers. The goal is to manage these towers centrally while ensuring they can function autonomously due to regulatory requirements.
** *Control Room Setup:* Setup involves multiple control rooms and airport towers, with central management of these towers being a key goal.
** *Autonomous Functioning:* Due to regulatory requirements, each tower must be able to function autonomously, even if disconnected from the main control room.
** *Regulatory Compliance:* The setup must comply with European and possibly global air traffic regulations, ensuring that towers can operate independently if needed.
* The project is substantial, with a budget of €5 million allocated for the next (2026) year, indicating a major opportunity for the company

+*Fit Criteria*+

* Source sharing shall only be possible for *non exclusive encoder sources* and between CTRL systems that:
** Belong to the same *Circle of Trust (CoT)*, and
** Each hold a valid *federation / source‑sharing licence*.
* All CTRL systems in a CoT shall behave as *peers* (no master–local concept); sharing can be configured in one or both directions between any pair of peers.
* If a non‑exclusive encoder source that is already being shared is changed to exclusive on the owning system, the system shall automatically *stop sharing* that source to all remote systems, mark this imported source as unavailable and prevent operators from opening it.
* An administrator on a system owning encoder sources shall be able to:
** Select one or more eligible, non-exclusive encoder sources and explicitly *share* them to another CTRL system in the same CoT.
** Configure “share all current and future encoder sources” towards a given remote system.
** Modify or revoke sharing (add/remove sources, or unshare all sources) at any time.
* A receiving system shall:
** Discover shared encoder sources from other CoT members and list them as *imported sources* in its source catalog.
** Treat imported encoder sources as *read‑only*; configuration and maintenance remain on the owning system.
* Operators on a receiving system shall be able to:
** Browse and open imported encoder sources using the same workflows as for local encoder sources.
** Clearly distinguish between *local* and *shared* sources in the UI (e.g. via prefix, grouping or column), without impacting normal operation, as suggested by UX.
* Source sharing shall be *non‑transitive*:
** A system may only share encoder sources that it owns; imported sources from another system shall *not* be shareable further.
* If a CoT member is removed (or leaves the CoT):
** Other systems shall remove that member’s trust information and associated API client credentials.
** Imported sources originating from that system shall be removed or marked as invalid/unavailable and no longer openable.
* In a *business continuity* scenario:
** It shall be possible for operators on one CTRL system to continue opening encoder sources owned by another system when that remote system’s CTRL/SAS cluster is down, provided the encoders remain reachable on the network and their IP information has not changed.

+*Fit Criteria (Non‑Functional)*+

* *Security*
** All CoT and source‑sharing communication between CTRL systems shall use *mutual TLS (mTLS)* with device/application certificates.
** Forming a CoT shall *not* automatically grant access to any sources; explicit source‑sharing configuration is required.
** Before a new system is fully trusted and admitted to a CoT, the UI shall not disclose detailed identities of existing members; at most, an aggregate member count may be shown (as per CoT security design).
* *Licensing & Scope*
** Each participating CTRL system shall require a *per‑site, non‑expiring licence* that enables CoT participation and encoder source sharing.
* *Network & Environment Preconditions*
** Source sharing of encoder streams shall rely on:
*** Correct *multicast routing* between sites.
*** Each site using its own *multicast range*, as per architecture proposal.
*** Proper *name resolution and routing* between CTRL systems (DNS and/or hosts).
** The product shall document these as customer responsibilities; the system will not perform network configuration itself.
** Version compatibility: all CoT members must run a CTRL version that supports CoT + source sharing and remains within the supported lifecycle window (1.5 years).
* *Reliability & Failover*
** The system shall cache or otherwise retain encoder addressing information such that, if a remote CTRL cluster is down but encoders are still reachable and have unchanged IP addresses, shared encoders remain openable from surviving CTRL systems.
** An administrative mechanism shall exist to clean up CoT membership, client data and imported sources for “dead” or decommissioned systems.
* *Scalability & Performance*
** The design shall support CoT deployments with *up to at least 50  CTRL systems and up to maximum of 10,000 of total sources (*including encoder sources) across them, without exceeding single‑system capacity limits for devices/sources.
** Under the targeted scale,  typical admin operations (browsing/filtering sources, changing sharing sets, viewing status) and operator operations (listing/opening shared sources) shall complete within acceptable response times for CTRL

+*Out of scope*+

* Any source type other than non exclusive encoder sources
* Wall list sync
* Desk List sync
* Maintainence functions like log download, backup, restore
*  User Federation is out of scope



{panel:bgColor=#deebff}
h2. Security Design Review – Circle of Trust (CoT) by [~accountid:712020:e059e4aa-65e1-4218-aabc-6970656f34ef] 

Secure design review security status {color:#36B37E}*[ OK ]*{color} 

We will cover all threat scenarios in more detail in the threat modeling. The threat modeling status can be found here. Please go through the document for further details: Barco CTRL - threat modeling - CoT (Circle of Trust) : Source Sharing Support. +Summary how current implemented functionalities work:+

# Toggling the "Encoder encryption" switch
===========================================
This calls the method "async def set_asset_type(self, asset_type: str):"  in curium  bases/curium/cm_device_service/apps/device_app.py L 3805
where asset_type = "barco-ctrl" if the switch is set to on
and asset_type = "EncoderManager" if the switch is switched off

This value is stored in the "asset_type_config" collection as property "asset_type" in the central-management database (=database used by curium)

For all activated ngs-d440 devices, the method "await device.set_encryption(args.asset_type == AssetType.BARCOCTRL)"  is called
This will set ["devicemode"] = {"encryption": encrypted}  into the config_desired (where encrypted is value passed to the device.set_encryption method).
This config_desired is then sent to spider-service ( await self._spider.put(f"devices/{self._deviceId}/config-desired", config_desired)) for storing it in the simone database 

so in the simone database in the devices collection, you will see for each ngs-d440 device the following property:
features["config@desired"]["devicemode"]["encryption'] = true or false depending whether the switch is on or off

The spider-service will upon saving also adapt some other properties in the config@desired upon saving:
You can see the full side-by-side diff of an ngs-d440 device config as stored in simone for the two cases (encryption on (=left) and encryption off (=right))
in file SimoneNgsD440DeviceConfigChangesEncryptedVsNonEncrypted.pdf (attached to this ticket)
!!! Please note that in config@desired, only the following is present:
            "devicemode": {
                "encryption": true
            },
There are no other changes (which is different for config@reported where the device reports the encryption state of every stream and also the urls depend upon the encryption state)

# Toggling the "Only allow devices with factory-installed certificates" switch
===============================================================================
Here via the maintain.proxy a call is issued to spider passing an array of trusted devices.
This array of trusted devices is stored in the "configuration" collection of the "simone" database under property "trustDevices" eg:
"trustDevices" : [
 "NGS-D320",
 "OPS-xxx"
]
In this way the system can remind the status of the switch and eg. HA and backup/restore can function.
At runtime, the values are also present in the trust_devices property of the SystemConfigure class, so a getter function can be created to retrieve the value from this class.

h1. TODO:

Spider to set a flag in config@desired to indicate whether legacy OPS support is active or not
It is then up to the encoder to apply the right subsampling
Current SAN FW version does not support the new 4:2:2 subsampling format, and for this reason decoders must be upgraded before encoders are upgraded, if not, you risk loosing the video stream during upgrade (depending on state of security switches)

As soon as TF-N mode is active or legacy OPS support is active, the encoder must use 4:2:0 subsampling
TF-N mode switch controls whether the video streams are encrypted before streaming out (already implemented)

Media team has found that the root cause for the GPU hang: [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-27521|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-27521|smart-link] 
which is marked as blocker for 1.11, is the addition of 4:2:2 chroma subsampling for AV encoded sources via NGS-D440.

Fixing the root cause to make 4:2:2 work without SAN GPU hang will need the support from Intel and will require time, therefore to not further block 1.11, *we need to revert to 4:2:0 for NGS-D440.*
while work continues to find root cause fixes to have 4:2:2 support without SAN GPU hangs, so we can ship 4:2:2 in the next version as soon as resolved

components.description: Apollo team: CTRL configuration & application feature team
components.name: Apollo

fields.description:
h2. Business Value

Barco CTRL was launched to market with AV sources encoded via NGS-D440 with *4:2:0* chroma subsampling.

Depending on the nature of the content, this can lead to color artifacts. This is most prominent on PC graphics content.

[https://www.rtings.com/tv/learn/chroma-subsampling|https://www.rtings.com/tv/learn/chroma-subsampling|smart-link] 

As the color artifacts, customers complained and PQM field quality tickets were raised.

Driven by this PQM defect: [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-24101|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-24101|smart-link] 
an advanced 4:2:2 chroma upsampling algorithm was implemented on the NGS-D440 encoder.
Also the SAN-050 decoder stack was adapted to play back this encoder profile.

Furthermore decoder performance testing has shown that there is no degradation in decoding performance as a resuilt of this chroma improvement.

We now want to roll this out as a general non-functional improvement from 4:2:0 to advanced 4:2:2 for AV encoded sources in Barco CTRL, as this will reduce color artifacts and improve image quality of AV sources played back in Barco CTRL

{panel:bgColor=#eae6ff}
the advanced 4:2:2 is still lower quality than native 4:4:4 and therefore does not remove the need to implement 4:4:4 support for AV encoded sources.
To add 4:4:4 support, we still need to support the L2P2 codec in CTRL by implementing this epic: [https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-2937|https://barco-nv.atlassian.net/browse/OCS0001-2937|smart-link] 
{panel}

h2. Constraints

{panel:bgColor=#fffae6}
to support advanced 4:2:2 end-2-end both the NGS-D440 encoder and SAN-050 decoder need to be upgraded.

* If one first upgrades the decoder, and then the encoder, all is fine. Source will play back.
* If one first upgrades the encoder, and then the decoder, *the source playback will drop, until the decoder is upgraded !* 
* in alignment with service, the request is to ship the improvement for encoder & decoder together in one release. The necessary KB and training will be done to warn for this scenario
{panel}

{panel:bgColor=#fffae6}
nVidia graphics cards are not able to decode and play back our advanced 4:2:2 algorithm.
Therefore when an OPS or NDN device with an nVidia graphics card is present in the system, then the encoder profile needs to drop back to standard 4:2:0 chroma subsampling.
{panel}

h2. Mitigation

To ensure NGS-D440 can still play on an OPS and NDN device, the system will take into account the OPS security loosening and TFN mode switches in CTRLsystem

* if OPS security loosening switch is enabled, to allow OPS devices in the system, *ALL NGS-D440 encoders* will fall back to *encrypted 4:2:0 streaming*
* if TFN mode switch is enabled, to support streaming to NDN devices in a TFN system, *ALL NGS-D440 encoders* will fall back to *unencrypted 4:2:0 streaming*

h2. Fit Criteria

(-) NGS-D440 encoder and SAN-050 decoder are upgraded to support advanced 4:2:2 chroma subsampling.

(-) this will be released in a single Barco CTRL version

(-) what’s new shall issue a warning that this version recommends to upgrade decoders first, and then encoders

(-) KB shall be created explaining the same

(-) decoder performance testing shall be done and product speciifcations updated as needed

(-) when OPS security loosening is enabled, ALL NGS-D440 in the system fall back to encrypted 4:2:0

(-) when TFN mode is enabled, ALL NGS-D440 in the system fall back to unecrypted 4:2:0 for play back on NDN, but will no longer play back on SAN & OPS decoder nodes in a CTRL system







h2.
